title: HOW DO I DISABLE THAT DAMNED ANNOYING MUTE TAB OPTION?
content:
HOW DO I DISABLE THAT DAMNED ANNOYING MUTE TAB OPTION? Of course that same question was asked years ago, but the solution no longer works. Why does one even have to ask about any specific thing like this? Why is there not a systematic list of these CSS options? Why do you keep constantly making unwanted changes with no evident opt-out while not actually fixing bugs reported years ago and which should be most trivial to fix (such as the left-right arrows in the tab bar staying when the number of tabs has gone down below the level making them necessary)?

This no longer works either: 

#urlbar-zoom-button {display:none!important}

How do I disable that damned annoying zoom indicator now?
creator: ersatzemail

title: FireFox Cannot Restore Bookmarks
content:
After an earlier problem with restoring bookmarks, I had been carefully backing them up in both json and HTML files.

(I had run a Verify which showed no problems before initiating the new round of backups .)

When FF again randomly deleted a bookmark folder and all sub-folders, I tried to restore from both the json and HTML files.

The json files show 7000+ items. The HTML files are c. 25MB.

When I try to use either to Import bookmarks, nothing happens (no bookmarks are restored) except a message appears at the bottom: 'No Items'.

Yes, I should have stopped using FF after the earlier problem - my bad.

But I like FF more than the alternatives, and had, before the earlier problem, had always been able to recover by a restore.

The bookmarks that were wiped out in the latest random delete were my entire history of everything that I had saved from the Web on government and international relations - hundreds of Web pages, dating back to the 2016 presidential election. There is no way I can recreate that, unlike the earlier random deletion that was quite small and easily recreated.

I will now stop using FF and shift to Chrome, even though it is a PITA to use and gives Google everything I do on the Web.
creator: sfbillm

title: How to save images without the popup asking for location?
content:

How can I get this done? it should be a feature easy to get since Firefox has evolved so much that we can customize almost anything nowadays... an extension by Firefox (or Recommended) that adds a button (a small one in the corner) to just download the image you're hovering over would be amazing but there is none atm.

title: FireFox Freaking Far Out
content:
Firefox has started to do strange things. I have security set to medium, as I have had it for several years now. All of a sudden, when I go to some sites (~70% of the time), it tells me that it cannot connect to a secure site, and do I want connect to the ‚ÄúHTTP: site or not. This happens with little known sites like https://www.usps.gov, https:/www.amazon.com, and, oh yes, https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/.

Also EVERY time I try and go to https://www.Google.com, I get a message that says,

‚ÄúSecure Connection Failed An error occurred during a connection to www.google.com. PR_END_OF_FILE_ERROR 

   The page you are trying to view cannot be shown because the authenticity of the received data could not be verified.    Please contact the website owners to inform them of this problem.‚Äù

Also, whenever I go from a page to another in a different tab, or separately, it takes between 15-20 seconds up to a couple of MINUTES.

I have to use Microsoft‚Äôs horrible (to ME) EDGE program, which does all of the above WITHOUT PROBLEMS, and almost instantly! I have removed Firefox (ALWAYS the latest version) several times, and have even edited the registry to rid it of any Mozilla remnants. Install a new copy. SAME THING even without loading logins or bookmarks!

PLEEEEEZE help! I have been a Firefox user since 1984, when it was introduced!
creator: Pandreasen

title: Downloading files - directly attach file to blank email on email client?
content:
Hi all. I am using Windows 10 OS and Microsoft Outlook for emails.

When presented with the dialog box for downloading/saving a file, can Firefox directly attach the downloaded file to a blank email using my email client?

I have done a one-line batch file (which seems to work with "open with") that has the command:

"C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\root\Office16\outlook.exe" /a %1

and it seems to work, but is there an official or quicker solution? one that doesn't have to involve browsing for the batch file (having to type * or *.* to not show only .exe/.com files) with the "open with" option?

Alternatively is there a right-click context menu with a "send to" or "email to" that opens the email client and a blank email with the downloaded file already attached? (Or possibly there is a mailto or sendto command that can be selected in "open with"?)

Thank you.
creator: nicolaschen
